name: The Ottomans: Khans, Caesars, and Caliphs
description: The Ottoman Empire has long been depicted as the Islamic, Asian antithesis of the Christian, European West. But the reality was starkly different: the Ottomans multiethnic, multilingual, and multireligious domain reached deep into Europe's heart.

name: The Ruin of All Witches: Life and Death in the New World
description: A gripping story of a family tragedy brought about by witch-hunting in Puritan New England that combines history, anthropology, sociology, politics, theology and psychology..

name: Devil-Land: England Under Siege, 1588-1688
description: A BOOK OF THE YEAR 2021, AS CHOSEN BY THE TIMES, NEW STATESMAN, TELEGRAPH AND TIMES LITERARY SUPPLEMENT.

name: Going to Church in Medieval England
description: An engaging, richly illustrated account of parish churches and churchgoers in England, from the Anglo-Saxons to the mid-sixteenth century.

name: God: An Anatomy
description: An astonishing and revelatory history that re-presents God as he was originally envisioned by ancient worshippersâ€”with a distinctly male body, and with superhuman powers, earthly passions, and a penchant for the fantastic and monstrous.

name: Fallen Idols: Twelve Statues That Made History

name: The First World War by Michael Howard (2003-03-13)
description: This book is written first world war. If you want to know about first world war, you must read it.

name: Democratic Enlightenment: Philosophy, Revolution, and Human Rights, 1750-1790
description: That the Enlightenment shaped modernity is uncontested. Yet remarkably few historians or philosophers have attempted to trace the process of ideas from the political and social turmoil of the late eighteenth century to the present day. This is precisely what Jonathan Israel now does.

name: The Religious Enlightenment: Protestants, Jews, and Catholics from London to Vienna
description: In intellectual and political culture today, the Enlightenment is routinely celebrated as the starting point of modernity and secular rationalism, or demonized as the source of a godless liberalism in conflict with religious faith
